newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistani cabinet approves anti-corruption bill.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani cabinet approves anti-corruption bill.

text.p: Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's cabinet approved a draft anti-corruption bill on Sunday, a government minister said.
Information minister Khalid Ahmed Khan Kharal told a news conference the bill would be submitted to the National Assembly (lower house of parliament) later on Sunday.

He did not release a text of the bill, but said it aimed to provide a "comprehensive system of across-the-board accountability" of public office-holders in Pakistan since the military coup of July 5, 1977.

That was when General Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq overthrew then prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Benazir's father. Zia, who executed Bhutto in 1979, later became president and ruled Pakistan for 11 years until his death in a mystery plane crash.
"The draft bill aims at preventing corrupt practices and provides a comprehensive procedure for trial and punishment for such practices," Kharal said.
Any constitutional amendment requires a two-thirds majority in both houses of parliament and the bill would therefore need support from the opposition to reach the statute book.
Kharal quoted Bhutto as saying she hoped the bill would deter future corruption as well as punish its past exponents.
Bhutto has frequently denied opposition charges that her three-year-old government is tainted with corruption.

The government has produced its anti-corruption bill under pressure from President Farooq Leghari, once seen as a Bhutto ally. Last month he urged government and opposition to cooperate in setting up parliamentary committees to tackle graft.
He proposed several legislative changes, including an amendment to bar those found guilty of misconduct from public office for seven years.
His action was seen as a rare step into the political fray for a president who had kept a low profile since he was elected after Bhutto came to power in October 1993.

Pakistan Muslim League leader Nawaz Sharif had earlier demanded a permanent judicial commission to probe corruption charges against government politicians and bureaucrats. Bhutto had said existing mechanisms were adequate.
